description: Learned borrowing from Latin coenobium (“monastery, monastic community”), from the Koine Greek κοινόβιον (koinóbion, “monastery, monastic community”), from κοινόβιος (koinóbios, “communal living”), from κοινός (koinós, “common, shared”) + βίος (bíos, “life”).

examples: There were the cenobia, or monasteries proper, where the life was according to the lines laid down by St Basil; and there were the lauras, wherein a semi-eremitical life was followed, the monks living in separate huts within the enclosure.
